title: R40455
content: The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (EPACT) P.L. 109-58, Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 (EESA) P.L. 110-343, and American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (ARRA) P.L. 111-5 contain tax provisions related to energy efficiency and renewable energy. Resources like the Tax Incentives Assistance Project (TIAP) provide information on federal incentives for consumers and businesses. The Tax Incentives Assistance Project (TIAP) provides information on federal tax incentives for consumers, businesses, and builders/manufacturers. The website includes updates on federal legislation, links to IRS tax forms, and information on Energy Star tax credits for energy efficiency, matching funds, grants, and financing opportunities provided by the Department of Energy (DOE). The U.S. Department of Energy Alternative Fuels and Advanced Vehicles Data Center (AFDC) website provides information on incentives for alternative fuels and vehicles, including grants, tax credits, loans, rebates, regulatory exemptions, fuel discounts, and technical assistance. State incentives are accessible through a national map and summary tables organized by type of incentive, regulation, technology/fuel, and user. The information is updated after each state legislature's session ends. The U.S. Department of Energy provides updated information on state and federal incentives for alternative fuels and advanced technologies. The website includes links to government sources for funding opportunities and solicitations for business funding. Clean Cities Coordinators can access this information to stay informed on available incentives. The Department of Housing and Urban Development offers Energy Efficient Mortgages to help homeowners finance energy-efficiency features. The Alliance to Save Energy provides information on tax credits for home improvements, hybrid vehicles, and solar energy. State and local incentives for energy efficiency are also listed on various websites. The Database of State Incentives for Renewables and Efficiency (DSIRE) website, sponsored by the Interstate Renewable Energy Council (IREC), provides information on energy efficiency and renewable energy incentives offered by state and local governments and utility companies. Users can access summary data through national and special topic maps, search by technology, sector, and incentive type, and the site is updated weekly. The U.S. Department of Energy's website provides information on the Weatherization Assistance Program, state activities, and renewable energy incentives. The Database of State Incentives for Renewables and Energy Efficiency (DSIRE) offers resources on biomass, energy efficiency, and federal incentives. The Environmental Protection Agency's Funding Database includes information on biomass and biogas funding. The Environmental Protection Agency, Database of State Incentives for Renewables and Energy Efficiency, Geothermal Heat Consortium, Alliance to Save Energy, Energy Star, and Solar Energy Industries Association offer various incentives and tax credits for renewable energy technologies such as geothermal heat pumps, solar energy, and fuel cells. The Solar Energy Industries Association, Tax Incentives Assistance Project, American Wind Energy Association, and Database of State Incentives for Renewables provide information on federal energy efficiency and renewable energy incentives. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 included various reports on energy efficiency, renewable energy legislation, tax policies, alcohol fuels incentives, biofuels, hybrid vehicles, alternative fuels, tidal and wave generation projects, wind power, and federal grants programs. The CFDA is the main source of federal grants program information, available online. Federal grants are typically awarded to states, local governments, universities, and tribal entities. Individuals can apply for funds through state energy offices or contacts listed in the CFDA program description. Grant opportunities are also posted on Grants.gov, allowing electronic application for competitive grants from federal agencies. The curr_chunk provides information on resources for grantseekers, including the Office CRS Report RL32159 and How to Develop and Write a Grant Proposal CRS Report RL34012.
